summary: This is an internal email from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, forwarding notes from a call with the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) Warden. The notes discuss prison count procedures and protocols for handling missing inmates, providing context for institutional operations following Jeffrey Epstein's death.

persons.name: Warden
persons.context: The Warden of the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) was interviewed by a U.S. Attorney and a Special Agent regarding prison count procedures and protocols for handling missing inmates.

connections.description: The AUSA (ME) interviewed the MCC Warden as part of an inquiry into prison procedures.
The Special Agent (SA) interviewed the MCC Warden alongside the AUSA.
The AUSA and the Special Agent conducted a joint interview of the MCC Warden.

events.title: Call with MCC Warden
events.description: An Assistant United States Attorney and a Special Agent interviewed the Warden of the Metropolitan Correctional Center regarding prison count procedures and protocols for handling missing inmates.

locations: One St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The document records an interview with the MCC Warden about prison count procedures, specifically what happens if a count is wrong or missing.

The Warden explained that if a count slip is false or not turned in, a 'bed book count' is conducted for the specific housing unit, and if that fails repeatedly, a whole institution count is performed.
The Warden stated he had never been part of a whole institution bed book count and had never been at an institution that didn't 'clear account'.
The protocol for a missing inmate, after counts fail to resolve the issue, is for the Warden to be notified, who then alerts the regional director.
The correspondence is dated November 2019, following Jeffrey Epstein's death in August 2019 at the MCC, suggesting it is part of a post-incident review of procedures.
